PROJECT PREPARATORY TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Justification 
1.  The  project  preparatory  technical  assistance  (PPTA)  will  support  the  finalization  of 
design  of  the  proposed  Health  Human  Resources  Sector  Development  Program  Phase  2 
(HHRSDP-2) in close consultation with Ministry of Health (MOH) and other stakeholders. The 
PPTA will study the technical, financial and economic viability of the proposed project and the 
required policy actions. Due diligence will be undertaken and documented to ensure compliance 
of the proposed project with ADB policies and requirements. It will produce draft Report and 
Recommendation of the President (RRP) and its linked documents.   
 
B.  Major Outputs and Activities 
2.  The PPTA will (i) prepare a comprehensive health sector analysis and road map; (ii) 
determine the technical, financial and economic feasibility of the proposed project; (iii) develop 
design and monitoring framework; (iv) determine project cost estimates and financing plan; (v) 
assess financial management, procurement, and implementation capacity of executing agency 
and  identify  risks  and  mitigation  measures;  (vi)  assess  potential  impacts  on  environment, 
involuntary  resettlement  and  indigenous  peoples  and  analyze  gender  issues;  (vii)  conduct 
economic and financial analysis, and (viii) determine implementation arrangements.  Based on 
these, the PPTA will prepare an RRP and linked documents, including a project administration 
manual that will guide overall implementation of the proposed project.

C.  Cost Estimate and Proposed Financing Arrangement

basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund-V. The government will provide counterpart 
support in the form of office space, counterpart staff, and other in-kind contribution. The detailed 
cost estimate is presented in Table A5.2.

D.  Consulting Services 
5.  Consultants  will  be  engaged  through  an  international  consulting  firm,  including  19 
person-months  of  international  consultant  inputs  and  79  national  consultant  inputs  in 
accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (March 2013, as amended from 
time  to  time).  The  quality-and  cost-based  selection,  using  simplified  technical  proposal 
procedures, will be followed. Individual consultants will be recruited either by the consulting firm 
or by ADB following ADB’s Individual Consultant Selection. Inputs by the consulting firm may be 
augmented by a small number of resource persons as needed, to be recruited by ADB in 
accordance with ADB procedures. The outline terms of reference for the project preparatory TA 
consultants are described in paras. 6 to 13.

6.  Health  Systems  Development  Expert  and  Team  Leader  (international,  4  person 
person-months)/ Health System Development Specialist and Deputy Team Leader (national, 
6 person-months). The consultants will be responsible for overall coordination, implementation, 
management, and report preparation for the PPTA. They will lead consultations and analytical 
work for strengthening the health systems including HHR. The consultants will lead the drafting 
of RRP, linked documents, and other deliverables with inputs from other consultants, and 
ensure timely submission of these to ADB. They expert will have (i) at least 15 years of 
experience in public health including at least 5 years in health sector reform in Asia preferably in 
Viet Nam, and as a team leader or deputy team leader; and (ii) a post-graduate degree in public 
health, health management, health economics, or a related field.  
 
7.  Health  Economist  and  Policy  Expert  (international,  3  person-months)/  Health 
Economist  and  Policy  Specialist  (national,  6  person-months).  The  consultants  will  be 
responsible for identifying and developing the needed policy actions to support achievement of 
the intended outcome and undertaking financial and economic due diligence on the program. 
They will have (i) at least 15 years of experience in economic and policy analysis, and planning 
for strengthening HHR and institutions, and (ii) a post-graduate degree in health economics, 
public health, health management, or a related field.   
 
8.   Health  Education  Expert  (international,  3  person-months)  and  Health  Education 
Specialist  (national, 6 person-months). The consultants will be responsible for undertaking 
required analytical work and providing advice on enhancing education and training of health 
professionals, particularly on the establishment of mechanisms to support the achievement of 
international standards. They will have (i) at least 15 years of experience in HHR development 
and strengthening of health education and training, and (ii) a post-graduate degree in public 
health, human resource development, health economics, or a related field.  
 
9.  Health  Infrastructure  Expert  (international,  2  person-months)  and  Health 
Infrastructure  Specialist  (national,  3  person-months).  The  consultants  will  work  on  the 
development of policy measures aimed at improving quality of health educational infrastructure 
and facilities based on international standards and the associated monitoring and evaluation 
systems to support such measures, including the preparation of detailed design. They will have

18  Appendix 5 
at least 10 years of work experience particularly in health infrastructure design at international 
standards, and a degree in engineering or a relevant field. 
 
10.  Social  Development  Expert  (international,  2  person-months),  Safeguards  Expert 
(Environment) (international, 1 person-month), Social Development Specialist (national, 3 
person months), and Safeguards Specialist (Environment) (national, 1 person months). The 
consultants will review government’s poverty reduction policy and strategy and conduct poverty, 
social analysis and gender analysis of the proposed project, including safeguards due diligence. 
The consultants will have at least 10 years of experience either in poverty and social analysis, 
gender mainstreaming in projects, or safeguards. 
 
11.  Financial  Management  Expert  (international,  2  person-months)  and  Financial 
Management Specialist (national, 6 person-months)/ Procurement Expert (international, 2 
person months) and Procurement Specialist (national, 6 person-months),  The consultants will 
conduct due diligence on the proposed project to assess risks, financial management and 
procurement capacity of the EA, and assist in preparing program and project documentation on 
costing,  fund  flow  arrangement,  procurement  plan  and  other  financial  due  diligence  in 
accordance with ADB policies and guidelines. The financial management consultants should 
have professional accountancy qualification (CPA or CA) and the procurement consultants will 
have postgraduate degree in business administration, public administration, or a related field. 
They will have at least 10 years of experience in project development.  
 
12.  Engineer (national, 6 person-months). The consultant will prepare a detailed project 
outline, land survey, and a study to support the technical, financial, and economic viability 
analysis of the project. The consultant will have at least 5 years of experience in conducting 
feasibility studies and project development. 
 
13.   Local Coordinator and Administrative Assistant (national, 18 person-months each). 
The consultants will facilitate coordination between government, consultants, and ADB; and 
support day-to-day and major activities of the PPTA. The consultants will have at least 5 years 
of relevant work experience with government or foreign-assisted projects.  
 
E.  Implementation Arrangements 
14.      ADB  will  be  the  executing  agency  for  the  PPTA.  The  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance 
Disbursement Handbook (2010 as amended time to time) will guide the disbursement of funds. 
The  PPTA  will  be  implemented  for  18  months  from  1  January  2016  to  30  June  2017. 
Consultants  will  closely  work  with  MOH,  HHRSDP  Project  Management  Unit,  and  other 
stakeholders. The government was advised that approval of the PPTA does not commit ADB to 
financing the proposed program.
